In addition to single ammonium cations, diammonium cat­
ions are also introduced to synthesize 2D perovskites. Diammo­
nium cations have an advantage that complex R
to form 2D layers and diammonium cations can eliminate van
der Waals gaps and directly connect the layers together.
perovskites were prepared by the solvent evaporation method.
Although the inorganic layers are slightly distorted by the spa­
tial constraints imposed by the diammonium cations, these
perovskites have a typical corner­sharing structure. Through the
crystallography in these 2D materials, the well­defined cation
positions showed slower cation movement and migration than
, which is capable of overcoming stability problems.
Organic layers containing functional groups have also been
adopted to synthesize 2D perovskites and bring new function­

stant due to the large exciton binding energy compared with

Kamminga et al. used four phenyl alkylammonium cations
with different alkyl chains of one to four carbons to prepare
single­crystal perovskites at room temperature by a layered
stability and can be stored in low humidity for several months
without damage. It is interesting that two compounds with
structure where inorganic layers are linked by corner­sharing
octahedra isolated by bilayers of organic cations.
However, with longer carbon chains, the 1D perovskites with
inorganic layers consisting of corner­sharing and face­sharing
octahedra are obtained. Subsequently, Ye’s group syn­
) perovskites by the same method. The source
of fluorescence and the behavior of excitons were confirmed by
experiments, and the quantum confinement effect caused by the
structural reorganization was demonstrated by calculation.
A series of phenyl­ and naphthyl­containing amine 2D perov­
skites with non­centrosymmetric structures were achieved
through a simple and high­yielding liquid­phase crystalliza­
These 2D perovskites possess broad white fluorescence
emission in the long­wavelength region resulting from
the inorganic layer distortion induced by the introduction of
In addition to lead 2D perovskites, many efforts have been
applied for the synthesis of non­lead 2D perovskites.
by liquid­phase crystallization in the argon atmosphere to
prevent oxidation. Unlike oxide perovskites, which were syn­
thesized at high temperatures, these materials could be pro­
duced at lower temperatures. When the precursor solution
